S7.T2.caption: TABLE II: Test accuracy, test loss and convergence speed of FedGSÂ vs ten federated approaches.

references:
Comparison among FedGSÂ and other federated approaches.
We take ten advanced federated approaches for comparison to show the state-of-the-art performance of the proposed FedGSÂ in the presence of non-i.i.d. data. The test accuracy, test loss, and training rounds required to reach the accuracy of 82% are listed in Table II, and detailed training curves are given in Fig. 6. Unless otherwise specified, all the comparison approaches use the local epoch e=5ğ‘’5e=5 by default. In the following, we will compare these approaches and analyze their results, respectively.

To sum up, FedAvgM, FedAdagrad, FedAdam, and FedYogi are generally better than other comparison approaches (some of which cannot even reach the accuracy of 82%, marked with â€œÃ—\timesâ€ in Table II). Instead, FedGSÂ achieves the state-of-the-art accuracy of 86.0%, which is 3.9% higher than the baseline and 3.5% higher than the averaged accuracy. In addition, FedGSÂ can also reach the accuracy of 82% in only 147 rounds, which is 3.3Ã—\times faster than FedAvg and reduces training rounds by 59% on average. These comprehensive experiments prove the effectiveness and efficiency of FedGS.
